questions.text: Using general terms like 'storage' instead of 'data store' is acceptable in Software Development exams.
questions.explanation: Examiners expect subject-specific terminology from the study design. General language signals weak understanding and costs marks.
questions.studyTip: Learn the exact terms from the study design—use them precisely.

questions.text: Strong responses use terminology directly from the VCE Applied Computing study design.
questions.explanation: Technical terminology demonstrates mastery. Terms like 'functional requirements', 'data integrity', and 'agile methodology' show you know the subject.
questions.studyTip: Make flashcards of study design terms. Use them in every answer.

questions.text: For a question asking you to 'explain', simply stating a fact without reasoning earns full marks.
questions.explanation: 'Explain' requires you to show WHY or HOW something works. A bare statement without reasoning is treated as incomplete.
questions.studyTip: 'State' = what. 'Describe' = what + detail. 'Explain' = what + why/how.

questions.text: Questions asking you to 'describe' require more detail than those asking you to 'state'.
questions.explanation: 'State' needs only a brief answer. 'Describe' needs elaboration. 'Explain' needs reasoning. Match your response depth to the command.
questions.studyTip: Underline command terms—they tell you exactly what's expected.

questions.text: When asked to 'justify' a choice, explaining why your option is good is sufficient for full marks.
questions.explanation: Justification requires comparison. You must explain why your choice is suitable AND why alternatives are unsuitable. Missing either loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Justify = why this works AND why the others don't.

questions.text: A complete justification explains both why your choice is appropriate and why alternatives are not.
questions.explanation: Full marks require discussing all options. State why your choice fits the scenario and explicitly reject alternatives with reasons.
questions.studyTip: Structure: 'X is suitable because... Y is unsuitable because...'

questions.text: General knowledge answers without case study references score just as well in Section C.
questions.explanation: Section C rewards application to the specific scenario. Generic answers that ignore the case study details earn significantly fewer marks.
questions.studyTip: Reference the case study by name—use specific details from it.

questions.text: High-scoring Section C responses link theoretical knowledge to specific case study details.
questions.explanation: Remove and refer to the case study insert throughout Section C. Quote specific requirements, constraints, or scenarios from it.
questions.studyTip: After writing your answer, ask: 'Did I mention the case study?'

questions.text: You should keep the case study insert attached to the question booklet for convenience.
questions.explanation: Remove the insert and place it beside you. Students who don't refer back to it miss crucial details and score lower in Section C.
questions.studyTip: First action in Section C: detach the insert. Reference it constantly.

questions.text: Removing the case study insert and referring to it while answering helps you score higher.
questions.explanation: Key details like data flows, system requirements, and constraints are in the insert. Missing them means missing marks.
questions.studyTip: Highlight key terms in the insert before answering questions.

questions.text: Writing everything you know about a topic ensures maximum marks.
questions.explanation: Answer what's asked, nothing more. Irrelevant information wastes time and suggests you don't understand the question.
questions.studyTip: 2 marks = 2 distinct points. 4 marks = 4 distinct points. No essays.

questions.text: The number of marks and lines provided guide how much detail is expected.
questions.explanation: More marks means more depth. Use the lines provided as a rough guide—don't write half a line for a 3-mark question.
questions.studyTip: Marks roughly equal the number of distinct things to include.

questions.text: Speed is more important than checking your responses match the question asked.
questions.explanation: Many students answer a different question than what was asked. Re-reading catches this and prevents avoidable mark loss.
questions.studyTip: Finish each question by re-reading it. Did you actually answer THAT?

questions.text: Re-reading each question after writing your response helps ensure you've answered correctly.
questions.explanation: This catches misread questions, incomplete answers, and missing case study links. It's time well spent.
questions.studyTip: Budget 30 seconds per question for a final check.

questions.text: In VCE pseudocode, using '=' for assignment and '==' for comparison is acceptable.
questions.explanation: VCE pseudocode uses ← for assignment and = for comparison. Using programming syntax like = or == costs marks.
questions.studyTip: Assignment: ← (arrow). Comparison: = (equals). Not == ever.

questions.text: The assignment operator in VCE pseudocode is the arrow symbol (←), not the equals sign.
questions.explanation: Write 'count ← count + 1' for assignment. Write 'If count = 10 Then' for comparison. Mixing these up loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Practice writing pseudocode by hand—muscle memory matters.

questions.text: If statements in pseudocode don't need an explicit 'End If' if the logic is clear.
questions.explanation: Every If statement must have a matching End If. Forgetting this is a common error that loses marks on pseudocode questions.
questions.studyTip: Write 'End If' immediately after writing 'If'—then fill in between.

questions.text: Every If statement in pseudocode must be closed with a corresponding End If.
questions.explanation: Proper structure is If... Then... [Else...] End If. Missing End If makes your logic ambiguous and incomplete.
questions.studyTip: Count your If statements. Count your End Ifs. They must match.

questions.text: In pseudocode, 'selection' refers to choosing items from a list or array.
questions.explanation: Selection refers to conditional statements (If/Then/Else). It's about choosing which code path to execute, not selecting data.
questions.studyTip: Selection = conditionals. Iteration = loops. Don't mix them up.

questions.text: Selection in pseudocode refers to If/Then/Else conditional structures.
questions.explanation: Selection means the program 'selects' which branch to follow based on a condition. It's represented as If/Then/Else statements.
questions.studyTip: Three structures: sequence, selection (If), iteration (loops).

questions.text: Functions and methods are the same thing and can be used interchangeably.
questions.explanation: Functions are standalone code blocks that can be called from anywhere. Methods are associated with objects and operate on that object's data.
questions.studyTip: Function = independent. Method = belongs to an object.

questions.text: Methods are called through an associated object, while functions can be called independently.
questions.explanation: Use a function when you need to pass input and return output without object context. Use a method when operating on object properties.
questions.studyTip: object.method() vs function(parameters)

concepts.title: Store numbers as strings when needed

questions.text: Phone numbers and postcodes should always be stored as integers because they contain only digits.
questions.explanation: Numbers not used for calculations should be strings. Integers drop leading zeros—'0412' becomes '412'. Postcodes starting with 0 get corrupted.
questions.studyTip: No arithmetic needed? Store it as a string to preserve formatting.

questions.text: Data like postcodes and phone numbers should be stored as strings to preserve leading zeros.
questions.explanation: Integer data types remove leading zeros automatically. Postcode '0230' becomes '230'. Always use string for formatted numeric data.
questions.studyTip: Leading zeros matter? String. Doing maths? Integer or float.

questions.text: A one-dimensional array is the best choice when you need to store fields of multiple data types.
questions.explanation: Arrays store single data types. For multiple data types (like customer ID as integer and name as string), use a record structure.
questions.studyTip: Multiple data types = record. Same data type = array.

questions.text: Records are appropriate when you need to store fields of different data types together.
questions.explanation: A record can hold Customer_ID (integer), Name (string), and Active (Boolean) together. Arrays and associative arrays can't do this effectively.
questions.studyTip: Justify records by referencing the data dictionary's mixed types.

questions.text: In a data flow diagram, the external entity and the data store are the same thing.
questions.explanation: External entities are outside the system (users, other systems). Data stores are internal storage within the system (databases, files).
questions.studyTip: External entity = outside system. Data store = inside system.

questions.text: External entities in DFDs represent people or systems outside the system boundary.
questions.explanation: External entities interact with the system but aren't part of it. They're usually shown as rectangles and represent sources or destinations of data.
questions.studyTip: Users, customers, other systems = external entities.

questions.text: A Level 1 DFD is identified by having only one process bubble.
questions.explanation: Level 1 DFDs have data stores and processes written as verbs. Having data stores is the key indicator, not the number of processes.
questions.studyTip: See a data store? It's Level 1. Context diagram has none.

questions.text: Level 1 data flow diagrams contain data stores and processes written as verbs.
questions.explanation: Context diagrams (Level 0) show the whole system as one process with no data stores. Level 1 breaks this down with data stores and verb-based processes.
questions.studyTip: Level 0 = system overview. Level 1 = internal detail with data stores.

questions.text: Data flows in DFDs can be labelled with general terms like 'information' or 'data'.
questions.explanation: Data flows must describe what data is actually flowing—'login_details', 'customer_record', not vague terms. Specificity earns marks.
questions.studyTip: Label data flows with exactly what's being transferred.

questions.text: Data flows should be labelled with specific names describing the actual data being transferred.
questions.explanation: Use names like 'login_status', 'order_confirmation', 'payment_details'. These show you understand what data moves between components.
questions.studyTip: Check the case study for exact field names to use in your DFD.

questions.text: Mock-ups show the logic and structure of an application, not just the appearance.
questions.explanation: Mock-ups only represent the user interface and its appearance. They don't show object methods, algorithms, or program logic.
questions.studyTip: Mock-up = looks. Pseudocode = logic. Object description = structure.

questions.text: Mock-ups design the user interface appearance, while pseudocode represents algorithm logic.
questions.explanation: Different design tools serve different purposes. Use mock-ups for UI, pseudocode for algorithms, object descriptions for class properties and methods.
questions.studyTip: Know which tool solves which design problem.

questions.text: Object descriptions are the same as pseudocode—both show how algorithms work.
questions.explanation: Object descriptions outline properties, methods, and events of objects in table form. Pseudocode shows step-by-step algorithm logic. They're different tools.
questions.studyTip: Object description = what an object HAS and DOES. Pseudocode = HOW.

questions.text: Object descriptions detail the properties, methods, and events of objects within a solution.
questions.explanation: They're typically tables listing name, type, and description. They describe the structure of classes/objects, not the algorithms inside methods.
questions.studyTip: Object descriptions answer: what attributes? what methods? what events?

questions.text: When testing a condition like 'If points > 5000', testing values like 4000 and 4500 is sufficient.
questions.explanation: You must test the boundary itself (5000), values just above (5001), and values below. Testing only 'below' values misses whether the boundary works.
questions.studyTip: Boundary testing: below, at, and above the boundary value.

questions.text: Boundary testing requires testing values at, above, and below the boundary condition.
questions.explanation: For 'If points >= 5000', test 4999 (below), 5000 (at), and 5001 (above). This catches off-by-one errors in conditions.
questions.studyTip: Three tests per boundary: boundary-1, boundary, boundary+1.

concepts.title: Identify the line with the error

questions.text: When asked to identify a line of pseudocode containing an error, writing 'line 4' is acceptable.
questions.explanation: Don't write line numbers—write the actual pseudocode. Examiners want to see you can identify the specific code, not just its location.
questions.studyTip: Write the actual code: 'If points > amount Then' not 'line 4'.

questions.text: When identifying erroneous pseudocode, you should write out the actual line of code, not just its number.
questions.explanation: Writing the code shows you've identified exactly what's wrong. Line numbers can be misread or misinterpreted.
questions.studyTip: Copy the faulty line exactly, then explain or fix it.

questions.text: Using the mathematical symbol ≥ instead of >= in pseudocode corrections is acceptable.
questions.explanation: VCE pseudocode uses >= not ≥. Mathematical symbols aren't accepted. Write 'If points >= amount Then' not 'If points ≥ amount Then'.
questions.studyTip: Pseudocode operators: >=, <=, <>, AND, OR, NOT.

questions.text: When correcting pseudocode, use text-based operators like >= rather than mathematical symbols like ≥.
questions.explanation: Stay consistent with pseudocode conventions. Use >= for greater than or equal, <= for less than or equal, <> for not equal.
questions.studyTip: Handwriting tip: make >= clearly two characters, not ≥.

questions.text: Developers who built the software are the best people to conduct usability testing.
questions.explanation: Developers have bias and know how the system 'should' work. End users who will actually use the software provide objective, realistic feedback.
questions.studyTip: Usability testing needs real users, not the people who built it.

questions.text: The client's employees should participate in usability testing because they will be the actual users.
questions.explanation: End users provide unbiased feedback about real usability issues. They'll find problems developers never notice.
questions.studyTip: Test with who will USE it, not who MADE it.

questions.text: Asking clarifying questions during usability testing improves the quality of feedback collected.
questions.explanation: Asking questions introduces bias—the tester might lead users toward certain responses. Recording video provides objective, uninfluenced data.
questions.studyTip: Video recording = objective. Interviewing during testing = biased.

questions.text: Recording video of usability tests provides objective data that multiple reviewers can analyse.
questions.explanation: Video can be watched multiple times by different people. It captures actual user behaviour without interviewer bias influencing responses.
questions.studyTip: Record tests. Review recordings. Avoid leading questions.

questions.text: A textbox is appropriate for selecting an Australian state because users can type what they want.
questions.explanation: Textboxes allow inconsistent data entry—users might type 'Victoria', 'Vic', 'VIC', or make typos. Use drop-down lists for fixed options.
questions.studyTip: Fixed options? Use drop-down/radio buttons. Free text? Use textbox.

questions.text: Drop-down lists or radio buttons should be used when input must be selected from a fixed set of options.
questions.explanation: These controls ensure data consistency—users can only select valid options. This prevents typos and variations that cause data quality issues.
questions.studyTip: Validation starts at input design. Constrain what users can enter.

questions.text: Waterfall is the best development model when client requirements are likely to change.
questions.explanation: Waterfall follows a fixed, sequential plan with no room for changes. Agile handles changing requirements through iterative sprints and continuous client communication.
questions.studyTip: Changing requirements = agile. Fixed requirements = waterfall.

questions.text: Agile development is suitable when requirements are unclear or subject to change.
questions.explanation: Agile runs in sprints with continuous client feedback, allowing requirements to evolve. Waterfall requires all requirements defined upfront.
questions.studyTip: Justify by comparing: 'Agile suits this because... unlike waterfall which...'

questions.text: If Task A takes 3 days and Task B takes 4 days, and both can run simultaneously, the total time is 7 days.
questions.explanation: Parallel tasks don't add up—they run at the same time. If A (3 days) and B (4 days) run simultaneously, total time is 4 days (the longer one).
questions.studyTip: Parallel tasks: take the longer duration, not the sum.

questions.text: When tasks run simultaneously, the total duration is the length of the longest task, not the sum.
questions.explanation: Gantt charts show parallel tasks running at the same time. Only sequential dependencies add to total project time. Parallel work saves time.
questions.studyTip: Read Gantt charts carefully—which tasks actually run in parallel?

questions.text: The only way to record project progress is to update the original project plan.
questions.explanation: Use annotations on the Gantt chart, maintain a log book, or create updated versions of the project plan. Multiple techniques are acceptable.
questions.studyTip: Progress tracking: annotations, log books, updated Gantt charts.

questions.text: Log books and annotations can track whether tasks and milestones were completed on schedule.
questions.explanation: Log books record changes, reasons, dates, and times. Annotations mark actual vs planned progress. Both help evaluate project management success.
questions.studyTip: Log book = what changed, when, and why.

questions.text: Assessing a project plan just requires checking if the project was completed.
questions.explanation: Evaluation should check: were all tasks identified? Were they scheduled appropriately? Were milestones achieved on time? Was the plan useful?
questions.studyTip: Evaluate the PLAN itself, not just the project outcome.

questions.text: Evaluating a project plan involves checking if tasks were scheduled appropriately and milestones met on time.
questions.explanation: Compare the updated plan to the initial plan. Did the plan help or hinder? Were dependencies correct? Were time estimates accurate?
questions.studyTip: Good evaluation question: 'Did the plan help us succeed, or cause problems?'

questions.text: Version control and backing up files are the same thing with different names.
questions.explanation: Version control tracks changes so you can roll back to previous versions. Backing up stores copies in multiple locations to prevent data loss.
questions.studyTip: Version control = track changes. Backup = prevent loss.

questions.text: Version control tracks changes to files for rollback, while backups store copies to prevent data loss.
questions.explanation: Use version control during development to track code changes. Use backups to protect against hardware failure, corruption, or accidental deletion.
questions.studyTip: Version control: why did it change? Backup: don't lose it.

questions.text: SQL injection is when users accidentally enter too much data into a form field.
questions.explanation: SQL injection is deliberate—attackers enter SQL commands into input fields to manipulate or access the database. It's a security attack, not an accident.
questions.studyTip: SQL injection: malicious code in form fields attacks the database.

questions.text: SQL injection allows attackers to manipulate database queries by entering malicious code in input fields.
questions.explanation: Attackers can gain unauthorised access, steal data, delete records, or crash the system. Mitigate with input validation and parameterised queries.
questions.studyTip: Prevent SQL injection: validate inputs, use parameterised queries.

questions.text: Data integrity characteristics include terms like 'consistency', 'security', and 'privacy'.
questions.explanation: Data integrity characteristics are: accuracy, authenticity, correctness, reasonableness, relevance, and timeliness. Don't invent characteristics.
questions.studyTip: Memorise the six: accuracy, authenticity, correctness, reasonableness, relevance, timeliness.

questions.text: Authenticity and timeliness are recognised characteristics of data integrity.
questions.explanation: Authenticity ensures data comes from a genuine source. Timeliness ensures data is current and not outdated. Both are official VCE terms.
questions.studyTip: Link characteristics to scenarios: expired codes = timeliness issue.

questions.text: A software audit is just another term for testing code for bugs and errors.
questions.explanation: Software audits check for security vulnerabilities, legal compliance, and whether specifications are met. Bug testing is part of development, not auditing.
questions.studyTip: Audit = security, legal, compliance. Testing = finding bugs.

questions.text: Software audits check for security vulnerabilities and verify legal and licensing requirements are met.
questions.explanation: Audits assess whether software meets security standards, complies with legislation, and fulfils functional specifications. They're evaluation activities.
questions.studyTip: Audit purposes: security risks, legal compliance, specification met.

questions.text: Backing up and version control are risk management strategies for security threats.
questions.explanation: These are security controls, not risk management strategies. Risk management involves identifying threats and applying countermeasures like penetration testing or security audits.
questions.studyTip: Risk management = proactive threat identification. Controls = reactive protection.

questions.text: Risk management strategies include security audits, penetration testing, and secure coding training.
questions.explanation: These techniques proactively identify and address security risks before they become problems. State the technique, responsibility, and timing.
questions.studyTip: Strategy structure: what technique + who's responsible + when.

questions.text: Cross-site scripting only affects the appearance of a website, not its data.
questions.explanation: XSS can hijack accounts, steal data, modify content, and destroy trust. It compromises authenticity and correctness of data integrity.
questions.studyTip: XSS impacts: account hijacking, data theft, reputation damage.

questions.text: Cross-site scripting can compromise data authenticity by allowing attackers to inject content.
questions.explanation: Injected scripts can modify data or impersonate users. Users can't trust content authenticity when malicious scripts run on the site.
questions.studyTip: XSS + authenticity: who really authored that content?

questions.text: When citing the Privacy Act, writing 'Privacy Act' without the year is acceptable.
questions.explanation: Always include the correct year—Privacy Act 1988. Without the year, you haven't fully identified the legislation and lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Privacy Act 1988. Copyright Act 1968. Always include the year.

questions.text: References to legislation must include the correct year to receive full marks.
questions.explanation: The year is part of the Act's official name. 'Privacy Act 1988' is correct; 'Privacy Act' alone is incomplete.
questions.studyTip: Make a list: Privacy Act 1988, Copyright Act 1968, Health Records Act 2001.

questions.text: If something is legal, it is automatically ethical.
questions.explanation: Legal compliance and ethical behaviour are different. Tracking user location might be legal with consent but ethically questionable without clear disclosure.
questions.studyTip: Legal = what you CAN do. Ethical = what you SHOULD do.

questions.text: An ethical issue can exist even when no laws have been broken.
questions.explanation: Using location data to track family members might be legal but raises ethical concerns about privacy and consent. Discuss the ethical impact, not just legality.
questions.studyTip: Ethics questions focus on trust, privacy, consent—not prosecution.

questions.text: Data collected during usability testing belongs to the users who participated.
questions.explanation: Testing data is typically a work product owned by the company that commissioned it. Copyright applies to this intellectual property.
questions.studyTip: Work products belong to the commissioning organisation.

questions.text: Data created during software development is intellectual property owned by the commissioning organisation.
questions.explanation: This includes test data, code, documentation. Employees can't take this data when they leave without breaching copyright and employment agreements.
questions.studyTip: Protect IP: access controls, agreements, revoke access on departure.

questions.text: Portability (which operating systems the solution runs on) is a functional requirement.
questions.explanation: Portability is a non-functional requirement—it describes characteristics of the solution, not what it does. Functional = what it does. Non-functional = how well.
questions.studyTip: Functional = features and actions. Non-functional = qualities and constraints.

questions.text: Reliability and usability are non-functional requirements describing solution characteristics.
questions.explanation: Non-functional requirements include reliability, usability, portability, security. They describe HOW the solution behaves, not WHAT it does.
questions.studyTip: Non-functional examples: must be 99.9% uptime, must run on iOS.

questions.text: Solution evaluation should happen immediately after implementation.
questions.explanation: Evaluation should occur 3-6 months after implementation. This gives time to assess real-world performance, user satisfaction, and whether objectives were met.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate 3-6 months post-implementation, not immediately.

questions.text: Solution evaluation is conducted several months after implementation to assess real-world performance.
questions.explanation: Immediate post-implementation is too early to judge success. Users need time to adopt the system and reveal issues that only appear with real use.
questions.studyTip: Don't confuse evaluation with testing. Testing = development. Evaluation = months later.

questions.text: CSV and XML have the same advantages, just different syntax.
questions.explanation: CSV is simpler and smaller. XML is more readable and interoperable between systems. They have different strengths for different situations.
questions.studyTip: CSV = small, simple. XML = readable, interoperable, self-describing.

questions.text: CSV files are smaller and simpler, while XML files are more human-readable and interoperable.
questions.explanation: Choose CSV for simple data with fixed fields. Choose XML when data needs to be shared between different systems or when structure needs to be self-describing.
questions.studyTip: Justify your file format choice by comparing advantages.

questions.text: XML files use commas to separate data fields, just like CSV files.
questions.explanation: XML uses custom tags to describe data: <name>John</name>. Tags make the structure self-describing. CSV uses delimiters with no field descriptions.
questions.studyTip: XML: tags describe data. CSV: delimiters separate data.

questions.text: XML uses custom tags that describe the data they contain, making the structure self-documenting.
questions.explanation: Each piece of data is wrapped in tags that explain what it is. This makes XML files easier for humans to read and for different systems to interpret.
questions.studyTip: Self-describing tags make XML ideal for data exchange between systems.

questions.text: Binary search is always faster than linear search, so you should always use it.
questions.explanation: Binary search requires sorted data. If data is sorted by Customer_ID but you're searching by Phone_Number, you must use linear search.
questions.studyTip: Binary search needs sorted data ON THE SEARCH FIELD.

questions.text: Linear search must be used when data is not sorted by the field you're searching on.
questions.explanation: Binary search only works on the sorted field. Searching an unsorted field requires checking each record sequentially with linear search.
questions.studyTip: Check: is data sorted by MY search field? No? Use linear.

questions.text: An SRS just needs to list what the software will do—style and clarity don't affect marks.
questions.explanation: SRS characteristics include clarity, completeness, consistency, and clear prioritisation. How you write it matters as much as what you include.
questions.studyTip: SRS needs: clarity, completeness, consistency, prioritisation, detail, relevance.

questions.text: A good SRS demonstrates clarity, completeness, and consistency in its requirements.
questions.explanation: Functional and non-functional requirements must be clear, complete, and consistent with each other. Include scope, constraints, and system requirements.
questions.studyTip: SRS components: scope, requirements (functional/non-functional), constraints, assumptions.
